Oh, I must weep — it soothes the lonely heart,</br>But little will my fondest tears avail—</br>The bark, that lost to guiding star and chart</br>Bounds on unknowingly before the gale,</br>Has pictured life in poet's ethic tale,</br>And it may picture mine — the hallowed star</br>That shewed the path has failed — I saw it fail—</br>I saw the gloom its lovely lustre mar,</br>Then sink, and slowly vanish, from the things that are.

Even now, methought, again I hailed its beam—</br>Beheld the joy of other days return—</br>How my fond heart did leap to hail the gleam</br>Of that sweet light that long had ceased to burn!</br>Ah no! . . . the dead will not forsake the urn—</br>It was a dream — 'twas sweet and swiftly o'er. . .</br>Like shipwrecked mariner alone and worn,</br>His treasure in the deep — himself on desert shore—</br>I see a wildering waste behind and dread to look before!

All woe-begone I laid me down to sleep,</br>And dreams arose — dreams of the silent dead—</br>I stood where Bertha's stream with azure sweep</br>Rolls its broad waters o'er their oozy bed—</br>The boughs were green, and waving o'er my head,</br>And Mary stood before me bathed in tears,</br>And lovely still, save that the glow had fled</br>Her lips and cheek — those lips in other years</br>That sweetly smiled me into love — its hopes and fears!

I rushed to fold her in my opening arms—</br>To weep away the sorrows of my breast—</br>To gaze once more upon those long lost charms. . .</br>"Sorrow no more," she said, "it breaks my rest. . .</br>That I do feel thy woes, those tears attest:</br>For spirits sympathize in human care—</br>The bourne is past — I mingle with the blest,</br>A little while and thou shalt meet me there,</br>To part no more" . . . she smiled, and melted into air. . .

I woke — the tear-drop gathered in my eye,</br>I felt that I had heard an angel's voice,</br>Bidding my troubled soul suppress its sigh,</br>And half my heart essayed to rejoice—</br>But oh, she was my bosom's early choice;</br>And while I dreamt of joy, the spoiler came. . . .</br>In her I saw the end of earthly joys—</br>And I must weep — I love to breathe her name,</br>But feel that wanting her, life has no farther aim. . . .</br>
